course.description: This course studies the concepts and evidence relevant to the management of investment portfolios. reviews.author: HKUST is good
reviews.title: Fascinating Content, Disgusting Professor
reviews.comment_content:
In terms of content, it is excellent.
You will learn well how to invest to maximise your realised return and lower your risk. Of course, this does not mean you can be a millionaire at Wall Street after studying FINA3103, because risk is risk.

You will learn:
-What is investment
-Risk aversion and Risk seeking
-Utility curve
-Portfolio Management (CAPM model, Index Model, Multi-factor Model, Arbitrage Pricing Theory)
(-midterm exam-)
-Efficient Market Hypothesis
-Behavioural Finance
-Evaluating Fund Manager
-Bonds (Yield Curve, Forward and spot interest rates, Duration and immunisation)
-Derivatives (Options and Futures)
(-Final Exam, cumulative-)

This course learn various investment approaches using the perspective of a general citizen, which is quite good and equip you with the knowledge in future when you want to invest your money.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Utpal teaching was extremely poor. His slides were very messy. Each lecture note had different fonts, different formats, different word sizes and colors...

Some professor might also provide unorganised slides, but could compensate with lively teaching. However, Utpal just couldn’t.

His accent was heavy and his handwriting on the slides and from visualiser was very cursive. I think apart from Indian students, no one could effectively understand what he taught in classes.

He said he encourage students to respond, but then whenever someone asked something that interrupted him or he thought is stupid, or was challenging him, he would simply either skip the question unanswered, or answer in a few words with no explanation behind and immediately keep on teaching / end the class.

Going to class is a waste of time, but you can’t skip because of the in-class quizzes. Reading the powerpoint slides was a difficult task. I strongly suggest you go for a textbook. You will find a lot of things seemingly uncorrelated from slides to slides are actually with better explanations behind. The textbook is more comprehensive and much easier to understand (tho u need to spend some time reading it). Trust me or not, you will find it worths if you aim for a good grade and you are not good with an Indian accent. Moreover, few questions in the exams might be mentioned none to little from classes and slides but were emphasised in the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is so-so. It might be considered a better-than-average grading, given it is a finance course and students are competitive. However, they were not transparent as final exam score was not released, plus the in-class quizzes and homework basically did not have suggested solutions and comments to correct/incorrect answers.

Breakdown of grading:
1. In-class quizzes (can be anytime during the 1hr20min lecture): 20%, count the best 20 from 24 classes, almost starting the first class during the add-drop till the last before the exam period.

Mean score expect 18-19 out of 20, I got 19.7.


2. Assignments, four in total: 20%. They were all lengthy Excel assignments. Since it was a group work, make sure you find somebody has some basic knowledge in Excel.

Mean: 19-19.5 out of 20, my group got 18.4


3. Midterm examination: 20%, moderate difficulty — 50 Multiple Choice / Short Answer questions, each is worth 4 points, total 200.

mean: 162 out of 200, standard deviation 19. I got 192.


4. Cumulative final examination: 40%, quite difficult and very lengthy — 5 MCQ/Short Ans + 15 Long Questions, each is worth 20 points, total 400.
I guess no one could finish all, I got 17 questions out of 20 done. Those were “done” only, don't know correct or not, but at least I know I left 3 questions unattempted

Everything about the final was not disclosed.


My final grade: A-
I will say the curving is reasonable. However, the assessments were too stressful and difficult, they would probably make u feel depressed after finishing them.
reviews.comment_workload:
Midterm and final exams were okay, all you need is to spend around 2-3 days for the midterm and 4-5 days for the final for revising. If u could understand the concepts and have some practices beforehand, those examinations should be fine.

However, in-class quizzes and homework were both demanding in terms of daily work. In-class quizzes forced you to understand the concepts taught (remember you will be with the poor accent and slides) in the class immediately. You need to digest the materials and you will only have 5 or 10 minutes each time for the quiz during the class. I advise you not to press the “start” button too early, better start a quiz after you have an idea on how to calculate or even you have done the calculation.

Assignments required the use of extensive Excel techniques and you may get pissed with those lengthy yet numeric raw data. Also, try to make good use of groups forming, better find someone who knows Excel beforehand but not a computer idiot.

reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to the syllabus attached.

Content is generally quite interesting. It covers the fundamental knowledge of the financial market and the basic management of investment portfolios. The professor also included some of his own research studies as teaching materials which are quite interesting. But don't worry those will not be in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is really bad. I have no idea how he can put "World’s Best B-School Professors" at the home page of Canvas. Maybe he is great with his publications, but definitely not his teaching.

First of all, his PowerPoint is useless as compared to the book. So if you guys want to get a good grade out of this course you must get the book. By only looking at his slides, you won't understand what he is trying to imply whatsoever. You will only understand after hearing his teaching in lectures. The slides are too brief and often not coherent.

Another thing to mention is his stupid quiz assessment scheme where you have to complete a quiz on every lesson based on the content taught in that lecture. Though only the best 20 will be counted out of 24 lectures, the quizzes are often quite challenging and sometimes not even related to the content of the lecture. There is no way you can get full marks without prior studies before lectures. So I would suggest you reading every lecture slide beforehand to get a grasp on what he is going to ask. A useful tip would be to pay attention to the page number at the bottom of every slide. He will hide the page for the question of the quiz so there will be a page missing in most of the slides he provided (e.g. page 8 jumped to page 10 indicates a quiz on page 9), unless the quiz is at the end of the class. Therefore, you can guess what he is going to quiz and at least get some preparation beforehand.

Finally, I want to express my disappointment that no exercises were provided to help students practice for exams. How do you suppose students to prepare for exams without any exercises? My suggestion is to look for ways to find solutions for the book which is what I did. You will feel much more secure when you have something to practice your understanding of the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is surprisingly a lot better than I expected.

For me:
Quiz: 19.4/20
Midterm: 188/200 (around 1 sd above mean) (50 MCQ)
assignment: 19.9/20
Final exam: unknown (20 long questions)
Grade: A (I expect to get A- so the grading is quite good)

I left around 2 questions blank in the final so the grading is better than expected. But don't get me wrong. The grading is solely judged upon the score that I have attained. I did not take into consideration the workload.
reviews.comment_workload:
As I have mentioned, the quiz assessment scheme is really annoying and time-consuming. You have to study every lecture slide or even reading the book before each lesson to get a good grade in the quiz. I was unfortunately assigned to a 9am class this semester so it was even tougher for me :(

His assignments are not difficult. Just remember to check with your groupmate to eliminate careless mistakes.

The midterm is relatively easy if you have a basic understanding of the course content. The final exam, however, is extremely long and challenging and most of the people could not finish it in time.

reviews.title: FINA 3103: Appreciation of Utpal's research
reviews.comment_content:
In this course, you will learn about the basics of financial investments.  

Note that the amount of content covered in the course is heavily dependent on the instructor.  Utpal had exactly double the amount of course content as the other prof this sem (Prof Yu Jialin)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Utpal is a really talented presenter.  However, sadly he just really isn't a good teacher.  His classes will feel like watching Ted talks, where its interesting to watch (assuming that you like finance to begin with) but very hard to actually pick something up from.

Since he covers double the content of other professors, he speeds through the content, so there are very little examples given and the explanations are not good enough.  Again, it's useful to get a brief idea but you're 100% screwed for exams if you just rely on his lectures alone.  (Also he likes to keep showing off his papers in class?? Wtf??)
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading **heavily** depends on your effort.  

Utpal's grading has very high volatility.  Extra effort can really improve your grade, but at the same time be a little lazy and you're grade will suffer.

If you are willing to put in a lot of effort and time for a chance of a better grade, go Utpal.  If you would prefer a more relaxed semester, go Yu Jialin.  (I sat in a few Jialin lectures and he is a really nice guy)

Also, make sure you copy down every single detail in your cheat sheet.  He asked what are the factors for the fama french 3 factor model in midterm and I didn't copy it down so I lost 8 marks just because of that.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 assignments
1 mid-term
1 final

If you don't want a C range, you really need to put in a fuck ton of effort.  Reading the textbook is a must in my opinion, because the professor just skims through the basics of each topic in class.

reviews.comment_grading:
Assessments:
[21%] 3 Individual Homeworks (mean: 6.72%, 6.75%, 6.46%)
[14%] 2 Group Homeworks (mean: 6.64%, 6.81%)
[30%] Midterm (mean: 91.17/98)
[35%] Group Project (undisclosed)

My Scores:
Full homework
Full midterm
Probably favorable peer review

Final Score: A

Even if it's a nice score, don't be deceived. If you're careless in midterm, it will cost you because you cannot rely on the 35% group project. It is a pain in the a** that everyone procrastinates during the last two weeks of the course. The assessment was poorly designed and in my opinion, peer evaluation is everything. The peer evaluation is unique, in that it asks you to rank your teammates' contribution (excluding yourself), from 1st, 2nd, and 3rd. Luckily, I was active in my group so I assume I received a series of 1sts. Group project scores were also undisclosed, so the lack of transparency is another slap to the face.
reviews.comment_workload: Besides assignments once every two weeks and the midterm during the first half, the workload is generally light. It is the last two weeks of the course that are hell. You have two group assignments and the poorly designed Group Project to procrastinate. Groupings are finalized a month after the course starts, then no exemplar is given for the Group Project. You are just expected to construct anywhere from a 20-40 page report. Friends who have asked the professor for guidance or inputs on their ideas for the essay were just told to freely do whatever they wanted. Finally, the professor gave in two weeks before the Group Project was due, and uploaded a 50-page thesis his PG student did for 4 years. And yes, we had two weeks left to do something similar. That's not all. The two outputs for Group Project are a report (28%) and presentation (7%) - our report was 27 pages long and the presentation had to be 20 minutes long. For the presentation, you have two options of recording it or presenting in class, and we did the former because you can retake the video. Piece of advice - if you're forced into Halis' class, choose the right groupmates to suffer with you because we filmed on the day that it was due.

reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty light compared to other 3000-level courses.

The 4 group assignments may take a little time if you aren't familiar with Excel. They are more practical and related to real-world problems, e.g. running regressions to confirm whether the results are in line with the model prediction. Interestingly, most of the time the answer is a big "no", so it shows the limitations of the models we've learned in class. Anyway, the skill-set to identify which model to use, which evaluation metric to stick onto, and to back-check the model validity is more important than learning the models themselves. Know how to do is a computer thing, but know what to do needs human brain power.

Strictly speaking though, we aren't really there yet as in the real world it involves grabbing information and identifying problems by ourselves. In the assignments all these are already done by the TA before they are released to us.

Overall workload manageable even if you do the assignments alone - each assignment only takes around 1 or 2 hours. That's why our group ended up just doing them individually and cross-checking our answers at the end. And I believe most of the groups can get perfect score for all 4 assignments except for a few outlier groups.

BTW try to familiarize yourself with Excel when you have the chance (esp if you find yourself using a hell lot of time in the assignments). If you don't know how to use basic functions such as Goal Seek, Excel Solver, etc, spend some time understanding them. In the workplace you can't say, "I'm not gonna spend time analyzing thousands of stocks using Excel". You just HAVE to, not to mention our TA has already done some preparatory work in the Excel file and we aren't even starting from the raw data.

Preparation for the exams should be manageable. Utpal provides a number of key questions from the textbooks in the revision session and I find going though them good enough for the exams. But again make sure that you budget your time carefully and don't get stuck at 1 particular question.
